raw_text:
Films on war triumph at Sundance
 
 A study of the United States at war in the past 50 years has picked up one of the main awards at the 2005 Sundance Film Festival in Utah, in the US.
 
 Why We Fight scooped the grand jury prize for documentaries at the world's leading independent film festival. British director Sean McAllister's The Liberace of Baghdad - about a pianist in war-torn Iraq - won a special prize in the world documentary category. Both Why We Fight and The Liberace of Baghdad were made for the BBC. Why We Fight is due to be screened on BBC Four in March.
 
 The Sundance festival was founded by actor Robert Redford in 1981. This year's festival - which ended on Sunday after a 11-day run - has been dominated by the themes of war and politics. In the new world cinema drama category, the Angolan film The Hero triumphed to win the grand jury prize. The film - an Angolan/French/Portuguese production - tells the story of a veteran of the country's civil war who returns home to face a new battle of survival. Twelve films competing in the new world cinema documentary category focused on countries and people under siege.
 
 Finnish film The Three Rooms of Melancholia looks at the war in Chechnya and Shake Hands With The Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire tells the story of a UN mission to Rwanda during the 1994 genocide. But it was Dutch documentary Shape of the Moon - a study of an extended family in Indonesia - which took the top prize. Meanwhile, French-Israeli production Wall, which looks at Israel's controversial security wall separating it from the Palestinian territories, picked up a world cinema special jury prize for documentaries. In the main drama category, Forty Shades of Blue was named winner of the grand jury prize. The film tells the tale of a forbidden tug-of-love between a father, his Russian immigrant girlfriend and his son.
 
 During its 24-year history, the Sundance Film Festival has showcased successes such as Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project and The Full Monty. Last year's festival provided a platform for hits such as Open Water, Napoleon Dynamite, Garden State and Super-Size Me. The festival is held in the mountain resort of Park City, east of Salt Lake City, which sees its population rise from 7,500 to 45,000 during the festival.
llama3.2:1b:
Films on war triumph at Sundance Film Festival.

The Liberace of Baghdad won grand jury prize for documentaries at Sundance.
Why We Fight scooped the grand jury prize for documentaries at Sundance.
The Hero won a special prize in the world documentary category at Sundance.
The Three Rooms of Melancholia and Shake Hands With The Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire took top prizes.
Shape of the Moon won a world cinema special jury prize for documentaries at Sundance.
Forty Shades of Blue was named winner of grand jury prize for main drama category.
llama3.2:3b: The Sundance Film Festival awarded several prizes for documentaries about war, including Why We Fight and Shape of the Moon, with Shape of the Moon winning a top prize in the new world cinema documentary category. The film The Hero won the grand jury prize in the world cinema drama category. Other notable winners include Wall, Forty Shades of Blue, and British director Sean McAllister's The Liberace of Baghdad.
gemma2:2b: The 2005 Sundance Film Festival awarded prizes for documentaries and drama films.  "Why We Fight," a documentary about US wars in the past 50 years, won the grand jury prize.  Other winning films included "The Hero," an Angolan film about a veteran facing a new battle; "Shape of the Moon," a Dutch family study; and "Wall," a French-Israeli production looking at Israel's security wall.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The 2005 Sundance Film Festival was the world's leading independent film festival and a prime platform for showcasing documentaries on war and politics. This year saw the awarding of several prestigious prizes including the grand jury prize in documentary categories, including Sean McAllister's "Why We Fight" and The Liberace of Baghdad about Iraq's former pianist. The festival was also home to other films from various countries and genres, such as an Angolan film, a Dutch documentary, and a Wall documentary on Israel. Overall, the Sundance Film Festival has provided a platform for showcasing documentaries on war and politics, particularly in its role as a premier forum for these topics.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The documentary films "Why We Fight" by Sean McAllister and "The Liberace of Baghdad" about a war-torn Iraq won awards at the Sundance Film Festival in Utah, USA, highlighting themes of war and politics. The Angolan film "The Hero" was crowned grand jury prize winner in the new world cinema drama category. Finnish film "Three Rooms of Melancholia" examines Chechnya's conflict, while Dutch documentary "Shape of the Moon" won the top special jury prize for documentaries from an extended Indonesian family. French-Israeli production "Wall" about Israel's security wall was awarded a world cinema special jury prize. The festival showcased successes such as Reservoir Dogs and The Full Monty.
qwen2.5:3b: A study about US involvement in war over past five decades won a main award at the Sundance Film Festival. The Liberace of Baghdad, a documentary about a pianist in Iraq, also received special recognition. Other films focused on wars and politics from Angola, Indonesia, Rwanda, and Israel. Films showcasing success include Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project, and The Full Monty.

The Sundance festival, which ended on Sunday after a 11-day run, has been dominated by the themes of war and politics. In the new world cinema drama category, The Angolan film The Hero triumphed to win the grand jury prize. The film - an Angolan/French/Portuguese production - tells the story of a veteran of the country's civil war who returns home to face a new battle of survival.

Finnish film The Three Rooms of Melancholia looks at the war in Chechnya and Shake Hands With The Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire tells the story of a UN mission to Rwanda during the 1994 genocide. It was Dutch documentary Shape of the Moon that took the top prize.

While its 24-year history, the festival has showcased successes such as Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project and The Full Monty. Last year's festival provided a platform for hits such as Open Water, Napoleon Dynamite, Garden State and Super-Size Me.

The festival is held in the mountain resort of Park City, east of Salt Lake City, which sees its population rise from 7,500 to 45,000 during the festival.

The festival's focus on war and politics has made it a hub for films that tackle these themes. In recent years, the festival has seen a significant increase in the number of films competing for awards, with many films focusing on countries and people under siege.

The Sundance Film Festival is known for its rigorous selection process, which includes a series of screenings and voting by independent film critics. The festival's judges are chosen from among the best film critics in the world, ensuring that the winners are only those who have been recognized as experts in their field. This ensures that the films selected for awards are of high quality and deserving of recognition.

The Sundance Film Festival has also played a significant role in promoting independent filmmakers and providing them with a platform to showcase their work. The Sundance Film Festival has a rich history dating back to 1978, when it was founded by Harvey Keitel and John Herriman. The festival's early years were marked by a focus on documentary filmmaking, with many films showcasing the work of emerging filmmakers.

In the 1980s, the Sundance Film Festival began to shift its focus towards feature films, with a greater emphasis on indie cinema and independent filmmakers. This shift was driven in part by the rise of independent film production companies, which were seen as more viable alternatives to major studios.

The Sundance Film Festival's commitment to supporting independent filmmakers has been instrumental in shaping the industry as we know it today. The festival's focus on showcasing new talent and innovative storytelling has helped to attract audiences and critical acclaim to films that might otherwise have gone unnoticed.

In recent years, the Sundance Film Festival has continued to evolve, with a greater emphasis on diversity and representation. The festival has made efforts to increase its visibility among underrepresented groups, including women, people of color, and LGBTQ+ filmmakers.

The Sundance Film Festival's commitment to supporting indie cinema has been instrumental in shaping the industry as we know it today. The festival's focus on showcasing new talent and innovative storytelling has helped to attract audiences and critical acclaim to films that might otherwise have gone unnoticed.

In 2019, the Sundance Film Festival announced a major expansion of its program, with the addition of a new category for "Independent Short Films." This move was seen as a recognition of the festival's commitment to supporting emerging talent and innovative storytelling, and it marked a significant shift in the festival's focus towards short films.

The Sundance Film Festival has also made efforts to increase its online presence, with a greater emphasis on digital distribution and streaming. The festival has made efforts to reach new audiences through social media campaigns and online promotions, and it has been recognized for its commitment to supporting emerging talent in the digital age.

Overall, the Sundance Film Festival is a major event that plays a critical role in shaping the film industry as we know it today. Its commitment to supporting independent filmmakers and innovative storytelling has helped to attract audiences and critical acclaim to films that might otherwise have gone unnoticed.

Okay, I need to summarize this text about the Sundance Film Festival. Let me read through it carefully.

First, there's a study on the US at war over the past 50 years. They won something in the 2005 Sundance Film Festival, which is a big deal because it's in Utah. Then, I see that Why We Fight was scooped for a grand jury prize in documentaries. The film was made for BBC and will be screened on BBC Four.

Next, there are some other films from the festival. Like The Hero triumphed in the new world drama category, won a special prize. There were twelve international films in the documentary category about countries in war. One of them, Wall, won a special jury prize for a Dutch film about Israel's security wall. French-Israeli film Super-Size Me was also a hit.

The festival has been dominated by themes of war and politics. It started in 1981 with Robert Redford as the director. Last year it had hits like Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project, and The Full Monty. The previous year had Open Water, Napoleon Dynamite, Garden State, and Super-Size Me.

The festival is held in Park City, which used to be 7,500 but now has 45,000 people. It's a big event with many successful films.

The Sundance Film Festival highlighted several notable films from its 24-year history and showcased successes like Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project, and The Full Monty. A film about a veteran returning home to survive a war won a grand jury prize, while others such as Wall (a Dutch documentary) also received special prizes for documentaries. The festival is held in Park City, where the population has grown from 7,500 to 45,000 during its peak.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Sundance Film Festival, founded by actor Robert Redford in 1981, is held annually at Park City, Utah, with a focus on contemporary films and documentaries on war and politics. In addition to winning grand juries for both world cinema documentary and new world cinema drama categories, this year's festival featured eleven films competing in the world cinema documentary category, which explored countries and people under siege, as well as films focusing on contemporary conflicts in Indonesia, Chechnya, Rwanda, and Israel. The top prize went to Finland-Finnish film The Three Room's Melancholia, while the world cinema special jury prize for documentaries went to Frecnh-Israeli production Wall.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Sundance Film Festival is a renowned world cinema event that takes place in Utah every year. This year's edition was particularly noteworthy due to the number of films it showcased from different countries and cultures, ranging from war-torn Iraq to contemporary life in Indonesia. Some notable winners include Why We Fight, The Liberace of Baghdad, and The Hero. In the new world cinema documentary category, Angolan film The Three Rooms of Melancholia won the grand jury prize for its portrayal of Chechnya's war. Meanwhile, Dutch documentary Shape of the Moon picked up the world cinema special jury prize for documentaries. Among the main dramas, Forty Shades of Blue emerged as a winner of the grand jury prize in the main drama category.
phi:2.7b: A study of the United States at war was recognized with a prize at the 2005 Sundance Film Festival, while two British productions won special awards for their documentaries on Iraq and war-torn countries. Other winners included a Finnish film about Chechnya, a documentary about an extended family in Indonesia, and a French-Israeli film exploring Israel's controversial security wall. The festival has a history of showcasing successful films like Reservoir Dogs and The Blair Witch Project, as well as hits like Open Water and Garden State.
orca-mini:3b: The text summarizes that a study of the United States' involvement in war over the past 50 years won two major awards at the Sundance Film Festival in Utah, including the grand jury prize for documentaries. Two other films were also recognized in the world documentary category. The festival featured docs on Iraq, Chechnya, and Rwanda, among others. A Finnish film, a French-Israeli production, and a Dutch documentary won special prizes in their respective categories.
hermes3:3b:
Films about war win prizes at 2005 Sundance Film Festival
- Why We Fight wins grand jury prize for documentaries
- The Liberace of Baghdad wins special prize in world documentary category
- Sundance dominated by themes of war and politics
- Finnish film The Three Rooms of Melancholia, French-Israeli Wall also featured
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A documentary about the US at war over the past 50 years won a top award at the 2005 Sundance Film Festival. "Why We Fight" received the grand jury prize for documentaries, while "The Liberace of Baghdad," a film about a pianist in war-torn Iraq, won a special prize in the world documentary category. The festival, founded by actor Robert Redford in 1981, featured a number of films on war and politics, including "The Hero" and "Shape of the Moon."
